{{Discrimination sidebar}} {{wikisource|Matthew Shepard and James Byrd, Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act}}
[[File:Matthew Shepard and James Byrd, Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act.jpg|alt=President Obama with Louvon Harris, Betty Byrd Boatner, and Judy Shepard|thumb|right|President [[Barack Obama]] greets Louvon Harris, left, Betty Byrd Boatner, right, both sisters of James Byrd Jr., and [[Judy Shepard]] at a reception commemorating the enactment of the legislation]]
The '''Matthew Shepard and James Byrd Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act''', also known as the '''Matthew Shepard Act''', is an American [[Act of Congress]], passed on October 22, 2009,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/columns/ci_13628360 |title=Matthew Shepard Hate Crimes Act passes Congress, finally |publisher=Mercurynews.com |date= |accessdate=December 30, 2012}}</ref> and signed into law by [[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama]] on October 28, 2009,<ref name="obama">{{cite news|url=http://thecaucus.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/10/28/obama-signs-hate-crimes-bill/|title=Obama Signs Hate Crimes Bill|publisher=nytimes.com|accessdate=September 29, 2013}}</ref> as a [[Rider (legislation)|rider]] to the National Defense Authorization Act for 2010 (H.R. 2647). Conceived as a response to the murders of [[Matthew Shepard]] and [[Murder of James Byrd Jr.|James Byrd Jr.]], both in 1998, the measure expands the [[Hate crimes in the United States|1969 United States federal hate-crime law]] to include crimes motivated by a victim's actual or perceived [[gender]], [[sexual orientation]], [[gender identity]], or [[disability]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/10/28/president-obama-signs-hate-crime-prevention-act/ |title=President Obama Signs Hate Crime Prevention Act |publisher=Fox News |date=October 28, 2009 |accessdate=September 29, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131006005532/http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2009/10/28/president-obama-signs-hate-crime-prevention-act/ |archive-date=2013-10-06 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
The bill also: * Removes, in the case of hate crimes related to the race, color, religion, or national origin of the victim, the prerequisite that the victim be engaging in a federally protected activity, like voting or going to school; * Gives federal authorities greater ability to engage in [[hate crime]]s investigations that local authorities choose not to pursue; * Provides $5 million per year in funding for fiscal years 2010 through 2012 to help state and local agencies pay for investigating and prosecuting hate crimes; * Requires the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] (FBI) to track statistics on hate crimes based on gender and gender identity (statistics for the other groups were already tracked).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hrc.org/laws_and_elections/5660.htm |title=Human Rights Campaign |publisher=hrc.org |accessdate=September 29, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081119235413/http://www.hrc.org/laws_and_elections/5660.htm |archivedate=November 19, 2008 |df= }}</ref><ref name="taskforce">{{cite web|url=http://www.thetaskforce.org/issues/hate_crimes_main_page/2007_legislation|title=Hate Crimes Protections 2007|work=National Gay and Lesbian Task Force|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927043549/http://www.thetaskforce.org/issues/hate_crimes_main_page/2007_legislation|archivedate=September 27, 2007|accessdate=December 9, 2009}}</ref>
== Origin == <!-- [[WP:NFCC]] violation: [[Image:Matthew Shepard.jpg|thumb|left|150px|[[Matthew Shepard]] (1976–1998)]] --> <!-- [[WP:NFCC]] violation: [[Image:JamesByrdJr..jpg|thumb|right|240px|James Byrd Jr. (1949–1998)]] --> The Act is named after [[Matthew Shepard]] and [[James Byrd Jr]].<ref name=ci>{{Cite news|url=http://coloradoindependent.com/39849/matthew-shepard-hate-crimes-act-passes-despite-gop-opposition|title=Matthew Shepard Hate Crimes Act passes despite GOP opposition | first=Joseph|last=Boven| date=October 9, 2009| accessdate=October 10, 2009 | publisher=[[Center for Independent Media|The Colorado Independent]] |quote =one of whom now admits to targeting Shepard for being gay}}</ref> Shepard was a student who was [[torture]]d and murdered in 1998 near [[Laramie, Wyoming]]. The attack was widely reported due to his being [[gay]], and the trial employed a [[gay panic defense]].<ref name=ci/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/2020/story?id=277685&page=1&singlePage=true#.UKlIgqXlf0c |title=New Details Emerge in Matthew Shepard Murder – ABC News |publisher=Abcnews.go.com |date=November 26, 2004 |accessdate=December 30, 2012}}</ref> Byrd was an [[African American]] man who was tied to a truck by two [[white supremacy|white supremacists]], dragged behind it, and [[Decapitation|decapitated]] in [[Jasper, Texas]], in 1998.<ref name=ci/> Shepard's murderers were given life sentences—in large part because his parents sought mercy for his killers. Two of Byrd's murderers were sentenced to death, while the third was sentenced to life in prison. All the convictions were obtained without the assistance of [[hate crime]]s laws, since none were applicable at the time.
The murders and subsequent trials brought national and international attention to the desire to amend [[United States|U.S.]] hate crime legislation at both the state and federal levels.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.tagesanzeiger.ch/ausland/amerika/Repraesentantenhaus-will-haertere-Strafen-bei-HassVerbrechen/story/19405418|title=Repräsentantenhaus will härtere Strafen bei "Hass-Verbrechen"|date=September 10, 2009|accessdate=October 10, 2009|publisher=[[Tages-Anzeiger]]}}</ref> Wyoming hate crime laws at the time did not recognize homosexuals as a suspect class,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adl.org/99hatecrime/provisions.asp|title=State Hate Crimes / Statutory Provisions|publisher=[[Anti-Defamation League]]|date=October 10, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629023522/http://www.adl.org/99hatecrime/provisions.asp|archivedate=June 29, 2011|df=}}</ref> whereas Texas had no hate crime laws at all.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://airwolf.lmtonline.com/news/archive/0608/pagea4.pdf|title=Black leaders honor Byrd Jr.|first=Stephanie|last=Elizondo|agency=Associated Press|publisher=[[Laredo Morning Times]]|page=4A|date=June 8, 1999|accessdate=October 10, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091229182843/http://airwolf.lmtonline.com/news/archive/0608/pagea4.pdf|archivedate=December 29, 2009|df=}}</ref>
Supporters of an expansion of hate crime laws argued that hate crimes are worse than regular crimes without a prejudiced motivation from a psychological perspective. The time it takes to mentally recover from a hate crime is almost twice as long as it is for a regular crime, and [[LGBT]] people often feel as if they are being punished for their sexuality, which leads to higher incidence of depression, anxiety, and [[post-traumatic stress disorder]].<ref name="sagepub2002">{{cite web|url=http://abs.sagepub.com/cgi/reprint/46/1/27|title=The Ripple Effect of the Matthew Shepard Murder: Impact on the Assumptive World Theory.|publisher=[[American Behavioral Scientist]]|year=2002}}</ref> They also cited the response to Shepard's murder by many LGBT people, especially youth, who reported going [[closeted|back into the closet]], fearing for their safety, experiencing a strong sense of self-loathing, and upset that the same thing could happen to them because of their sexual orientation.<ref name="sagepub2002"/>
== Background == The 1969 federal hate-crime law ({{uscsub|18|245|b|2}}) extends to crimes motivated by actual or perceived [[Race (classification of human beings)|race]], [[Human skin color|color]], [[religion]], or [[national origin]], and only while the victim is engaging in a federally protected activity, like voting or going to school.<ref name="nyt">Stout, D. [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/04/washington/04hate.html House Votes to Expand Hate Crime Protection], [[New York Times]], May 3, 2007. Retrieved May 3, 2007.</ref> Penalties, under both the existing law and the LLEHCPA (Local Law Enforcement Hate Crimes Prevention Act, originally called the "Local Law Enforcement Enhancement Act"), for [[hate crime]]s involving [[firearms]] are prison terms of up to 10 years, while crimes involving [[kidnapping]], [[sexual assault]], or [[murder]] can bring [[life in prison]]. In 1990, Congress passed the Hate Crimes Statistics Act which allowed the government to count the incidence of hate crimes based on religion, race, national origin, and sexual orientation. However, a sentence was added onto the end of bill stating that federal funds should not be used to "promote or encourage homosexuality".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://abs.sagepub.com/cgi/reprint/46/1/173 |title=Gay Adolescents and Suicide: Understanding the Association |publisher=[[American Behavioral Scientist]] |year=2002}}</ref>
According to FBI statistics, of the over 113,000 hate crimes since 1991, 55% were motivated by racial bias, 17% by religious bias, 14% sexual orientation bias, 14% ethnicity bias, and 1% disability bias.<ref name="sagepub2002"/><ref>Abrams, J., "[https://www.theguardian.com/worldlatest/story/0,,-6605760,00.html House Passes Extended Hate Crimes Bill]", ''[[The Guardian]]'', May 3, 2007. Retrieved on May 3, 2007.</ref>
Although not necessarily on the same scale as Matthew Shepard's murder, violent incidences against gays and lesbians occur frequently. Gay and lesbian people are often verbally abused, assaulted both physically and sexually, and threatened not just by peers and strangers, but also by family members.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/cgi/content/full/113/6/1827|title=Sexual Orientation and Adolescents.|journal=[[Pediatrics (journal)|Pediatrics]] |year=2004}}</ref> One study of 192 gay men aged 14–21 found that approximately 1/3 reported being verbally assaulted by at least one family member when they came out and another 10% reported being physically assaulted.<ref name="findarticles2005">{{cite web|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m2248/is_159_40/ai_n15950408/|title=Gay Adolescents and Suicide: Understanding the Association.|publisher=[[Adolescence]]|year=2005}}</ref> Gay and lesbian youth are particularly prone to victimization. A nationwide study of over 9,000 gay high school students revealed that 24% of gay men and 11% of gay women reported being victimized at least ten times a year due to their sexual orientation.<ref name="findarticles2005"/> Victims often experience severe depression, a sense of helplessness, low self-esteem, and frequent suicidal thoughts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://arjournals.annualreviews.org/doi/abs/10.1146/annurev.clinpsy.3.022806.091510|title=Sexual Orienation and Mental Health.|publisher=[[Annual Review of Clinical Psychology]]|year=2007}}</ref> Gay youth are two to four times more likely to be threatened with a deadly weapon at school and miss more days of school than their heterosexual peers. Further, they are two to seven times more likely to attempt suicide. Some feel these issues, the societal stigma around homosexuality and fear of bias-motivated attack, lead to gay men and women, especially teenagers, becoming more likely to abuse drugs such as marijuana and cocaine and alcohol, have unprotected sex with multiple sexual partners, find themselves in unwanted sexual situations, have body image and eating disorders, and be at higher risk for STDs and HIV/AIDS.<ref name="findarticles2005"/>
The Act was supported by thirty-one state [[Attorney General|Attorneys General]] and over 210 national law enforcement, professional, education, civil rights, religious, and civic organizations, including the [[AFL-CIO]], the [[American Medical Association]], the [[American Psychological Association]], and the [[NAACP]].<ref>[http://www.hrc.org/Content/NavigationMenu/HRC/Get_Informed/Federal_Legislation/LLEEA_Coalition_Endorsement_Fact_Sheet/LLEEA_Coalition_Endorsement_Fact_Sheet.htm Supporters for this legislation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070516110138/http://www.hrc.org/Content/NavigationMenu/HRC/Get_Informed/Federal_Legislation/LLEEA_Coalition_Endorsement_Fact_Sheet/LLEEA_Coalition_Endorsement_Fact_Sheet.htm |date=2007-05-16 }}, [[Human Rights Campaign]]. Retrieved March 5, 2007.</ref> A November 2001 poll indicated that 73% of Americans were in favor of hate-crime legislation covering sexual orientation.<ref>[http://www.hrc.org/laws_and_elections/5660.htm The Local Law Enforcement Hate Crimes Prevention Act / Matthew Shepard Act] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081119235413/http://www.hrc.org/laws_and_elections/5660.htm |date=2008-11-19 }}, [[Human Rights Campaign]]. Retrieved September 27, 2007.</ref>
The LLEHCPA was introduced in substantially similar form in each Congress since the [[105th United States Congress|105th Congress]] in 1999. The 2007 bill expanded on the earlier versions by including [[transgender]] provisions and making it explicit that the law should not be interpreted to restrict people's freedom of speech or association.<ref>[http://www.matthewshepard.org/site/DocServer/HRC-LLEHCPA-FAQ1-17-07.pdf?docID=463 Questions and Answers: The Local Law Enforcement Hate Crimes Prevention Act] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928140450/http://www.matthewshepard.org/site/DocServer/HRC-LLEHCPA-FAQ1-17-07.pdf?docID=463 |date=2007-09-28 }}, [[Human Rights Campaign]]. Retrieved on May 4, 2007.</ref>
==Opposition== [[James Dobson]], founder of the [[Social conservativism|socially conservative]] [[Focus on the Family]], opposed the Act, arguing that it would effectively "muzzle people of faith who dare to express their moral and biblical concerns about homosexuality".<ref name="nyt" /><ref>{{cite web |url= http://onenewsnow.com/culture/2014/04/17/activists-travelogue-reveals-impact-of-canadas-hate-speech-law#.U1CDEVf_kkI |title= Activist's travelogue reveals impact of Canada's 'hate speech' law |publisher= onenewsnow.com |access-date= 2014-04-18 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20140419025947/http://onenewsnow.com/culture/2014/04/17/activists-travelogue-reveals-impact-of-canadas-hate-speech-law#.U1CDEVf_kkI#.U1CDEVf_kkI |archive-date= 2014-04-19 |dead-url= yes |df= }}</ref> However, H.R. 1592 contains a "Rule of Construction" which specifically provides that "Nothing in this Act...shall be construed to prohibit any expressive conduct protected from legal prohibition by, or any activities protected by the free speech or free exercise clauses of, the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment to the Constitution]]".<ref>Text of {{USBill|110|HR|1592}} "Referred to Senate Committee after being Received from House" as accessed on October 2, 2007; the text of {{USBill|110|S|1105}} accessed on the same date does not include this section.</ref>
Senator [[Jeff Sessions]], among other Senators, was concerned that the bill would not protect all individuals equally.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usdoj.gov/ag/testimony/2009/ag-testimony-090625.html |title=USDOJ.gov |publisher=USDOJ.gov |date= |accessdate=December 30, 2012}}</ref> Senator [[Jim DeMint]] of [[South Carolina]] spoke against the bill, saying that it was unnecessary, that it violated the [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|14th Amendment]], and that it would be a step closer to the prosecution of "[[Thoughtcrime|thought crimes]]".<ref name="DeMint">{{cite news | publisher = The Guardian | date = October 23, 2009 | accessdate = December 10, 2009 | title = Judges barred from demanding doctor's notes in transgender name change cases | last = Nasaw | first = Daniel | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/oct/23/transgender-lgbt-name-change-new-york}}</ref><ref name="DeMint2">{{cite web | title=DeMint Speech Against Hate Crimes Legislation Attached to Defense Authorization | work=Speeches – News Room – United States Senator Jim DeMint | url=http://www.demint.senate.gov/public/index.cfm?p=Speeches&ContentRecord_id=81da21e0-b409-76ba-cdc9-42b7df029e3d&ContentType_id=08d747dd-8c3f-4b8c-87fb-4522a138d510 | accessdate=October 8, 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121214084738/http://www.demint.senate.gov/public/index.cfm?p=Speeches&ContentRecord_id=81da21e0-b409-76ba-cdc9-42b7df029e3d&ContentType_id=08d747dd-8c3f-4b8c-87fb-4522a138d510 | archivedate=December 14, 2012 | df= }}</ref> Four members of the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights wrote a letter stating their opposition to the bill, citing concerns of [[double jeopardy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marylandthursdaymeeting.com/Archives/SpecialWebDocuments2009/Civil_Rights_Comm._Ltr-1.pdf |title=open letter |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=December 30, 2012}}</ref>
== Legislative progress ==
=== 107th to 109th congress === The bill was first introduced into the [[107th United States Congress|107 Congress]]'s [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] on April 3, 2001, by Rep. [[John Conyers]] and was referred to the [[United States House Judiciary Subcommittee on Crime, Terrorism, and Homeland Security|Subcommittee on Crime]]. The bill died when it failed to advance in the committee.
It was reintroduced by Rep. Conyers in the [[108th United States Congress|108th]] and [[109th United States Congress|109th]] congresses (on April 22, 2004, and May 26, 2005, respectively). As previously, it died both times when it failed to advance in committee.
Similar legislation was introduced by Sen. [[Gordon H. Smith]] (R–OR) as an amendment to the [[Ronald W. Reagan National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2005]] ({{USBill|108|S.|2400}}) on June 14, 2004. Although the amendment passed the U.S. Senate by a vote of 65–33,<ref>{{USSRollCall|108|2|114}}</ref> it was later removed by conference committee.
=== 110th Congress === {{see also|110th United States Congress}} The bill was introduced for the fourth time into the House on March 30, 2007, by Conyers. The 2007 version of the bill added gender identity to the list of suspect classes for prosecution of hate crimes. The bill was again referred to the [[Subcommittee on Crime, Terrorism and Homeland Security]].
[[File:H.R. 1592 - Local Law Enforcement Hate Crimes Prevention Act of 2007 - House of Representatives vote.svg|thumb|400px|right|House vote on '''Local Law Enforcement Hate Crimes Prevention Act of 2007''' {{legend|#000080|Democratic yes}} {{legend|#FF5050|Republican yes}} {{legend|#C8C8C8|Abstention or no representative seated}} {{legend|#5050FF|Democratic no}} {{legend|#800000|Republican no}}]]
The bill passed the subcommittee by [[voice vote]] and the full [[United States House Judiciary Committee|House Judiciary Committee]] by a vote of 20–14. The bill then proceeded to the full House, where it was passed on May 3, 2007, with a vote of 237–180 with Representative [[Barney Frank]], one of two openly gay members of the House at the time, presiding.<ref>Simon, R. [http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-na-hate4may04,0,3438099.story?track=mostviewed-homepage Bush threatens to veto expansion of hate-crime law], [[Los Angeles Times]], May 3, 2007. Retrieved on May 3, 2007.</ref>
The bill then proceeded to the [[United States Senate|U.S. Senate]], where it was introduced by Senator [[Ted Kennedy]] and Senator [[Gordon Smith (politician)|Gordon Smith]] on April 12, 2007. It was referred to the [[Senate Judiciary Committee]]. The bill died when it failed to advance in the Senate committee.
On July 11, 2007, Kennedy attempted to introduce the bill again as an amendment to the Senate Defense Reauthorization bill ({{USBill|110|H.R.|1585}}). The Senate hate crime amendment had 44 cosponsors, including four Republicans. After Republicans staged a filibuster on a troop-withdrawal amendment to the defense bill, Senate Majority Leader [[Harry Reid]] delayed the votes on the hate crime amendment and the defense bill until September.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.washblade.com/thelatest/thelatest.cfm?blog_id=13543|title=Hate crimes bill in limbo|last=Chibbaro|first=Lou|work=Washington Blade|date=July 26, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928012004/http://www.washblade.com/thelatest/thelatest.cfm?blog_id=13543|archivedate=September 28, 2007}}</ref>
The bill passed the Senate on September 27, 2007, as an amendment to the Defense Reauthorization bill. The [[cloture]] vote was 60–39 in favor. The amendment was then approved by voice vote.<ref>{{cite web |author=One-Time Gifts |url=http://www.hrc.org/news/7747.htm |title=Senate Passage of Hate Crimes Bill Moves Bill Closer Than Ever To Becoming Law |publisher=HRC |date= |accessdate=December 30, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402210756/http://www.hrc.org/news/7747.htm |archivedate=April 2, 2012 |df= }}</ref> President Bush indicated he might veto the DoD authorization bill if it reached his desk with the hate crimes legislation attached.<ref>[http://www.whitehouse.gov/omb/legislative/sap/110-1/hr1592sap-h.pdf Statement of Administration Policy] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070509132516/http://www.whitehouse.gov/omb/legislative/sap/110-1/hr1592sap-h.pdf |date=2007-05-09 }}, Executive Office of the President, Office of Management and Budget. Retrieved May 9, 2007.</ref><ref>"[http://www.pinknews.co.uk/news/articles/2005-5582.html US Senate passes gay hate crimes law]", PinkNews.co.uk.</ref> Ultimately, the amendment was dropped by the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] leadership because of opposition from [[antiwar]] Democrats, conservative groups, and Bush.<ref name="windy">{{cite news|url=http://www.windycitymediagroup.com/gay/lesbian/news/ARTICLE.php?AID=17078|title=Congress Drops Hate-Crimes Bill|first=Amy|last=Wooten|date=January 1, 2008|accessdate=July 31, 2008|work=[[Windy City Times]]}}</ref>
In late 2008, then-President-elect [[Barack Obama]]'s website stated that one of the goals of his new administration would be to see the bill passed.<ref name="changedotgov">{{cite news|url=http://change.gov/agenda/civil_rights_agenda/|title=Plan to Strengthen Civil Rights|accessdate=February 18, 2009|work=The Office of the President-Elect|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090217091405/http://change.gov/agenda/civil_rights_agenda|archivedate=February 17, 2009|df=}}</ref>
=== 111th Congress === {{see also|111th United States Congress}}
==== House ==== [[File:111th Congress House roll call 223.svg|thumb|400px|right|House vote by congressional district {{legend|#000080|Democratic yes}} {{legend|#FF5050|Republican yes}} {{legend|#C8C8C8|Abstention or no representative seated}} {{legend|#5050FF|Democratic no}} {{legend|#800000|Republican no}}]] Conyers introduced the bill for the fifth time into the House on April 2, 2009. In his introductory speech, he claimed that many law enforcement groups, such as the [[International Association of Chiefs of Police]], the [[National Sheriffs Association]] and 31 state Attorneys General support the bill<ref>{{cite web|url=http://frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/getpage.cgi?dbname=2009_record&page=E878&position=all|title=Introduction of the Local Law Enforcement Hate Crimes Prevention Act of 2009|accessdate=June 18, 2009|date=April 2, 2009}}</ref> and that the impact hate violence has on communities justifies federal involvement.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/getpage.cgi?dbname=2009_record&page=E879&position=all|title=Introduction of the Local Law Enforcement Hate Crimes Prevention Act of 2009|accessdate=June 18, 2009|date=April 2, 2009}}</ref>
The bill was immediately referred to the full [[United States House Committee on the Judiciary|Judiciary Committee]], where it passed by a vote of 15–12 on April 23, 2009.<ref name="passjudcomm2">{{cite web|url=https://www.congress.gov/congressional-report/111th-congress/house-report/86/2|title=H. Rept. 111-86 - LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT HATE CRIMES PREVENTION ACT OF 2009|work=Congressional Record|accessdate=September 23, 2013}}</ref>
On April 28, 2009, Rep. [[Mike Honda]] ([[U.S. Democratic Party|D]]-[[California|CA]]) claimed that if the bill were passed it may help prevent the murders of transgender Americans, such as the murder of [[Angie Zapata]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Expressing Support for "Local Law Enforcement Hate Crimes Prevention Act (LLEHCPA)/Matthew Shepard Act"|url=http://frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/getpage.cgi?dbname=2009_record&page=E1004&position=all|date=April 28, 2009|accessdate=June 21, 2009}}</ref> Conversely, Rep. [[Steve King]] ([[U.S. Republican Party|R]]-[[Iowa|IA]]) claimed that the bill was an expansion of a category of "thought crimes" and compared the bill to the book ''[[Nineteen Eighty-Four]]''.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=IowaPolitics.com |date=April 28, 2009 |url=http://www.iowapolitics.com/index.iml?Article=156914 |title=Nineteen Eighty-Four |accessdate=June 18, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090520131111/http://www.iowapolitics.com/index.iml?Article=156914 |archivedate=May 20, 2009 }}</ref> That same day, the [[United States House Committee on Rules|House Rules Committee]] allowed one hour and 20 minutes for debate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rules.house.gov/SpecialRules_details.aspx?NewsID=4233|title=H.R. 1913 – Local Law Enforcement Hate Crimes Prevention Act of 2009|publisher=United States House of Representatives Committee on Rules|accessdate=June 18, 2009|date=April 28, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090625025627/http://www.rules.house.gov/SpecialRules_details.aspx?NewsID=4233|archivedate=June 25, 2009|df=}}</ref>
The bill then moved to the full House, for debate. During the debate, Rep. [[Jan Schakowsky]] (D-[[Illinois|IL]]) claimed that the bill would help prevent murders such as those of spree killer [[Benjamin Nathaniel Smith]] and would take "an important step" towards a more just society.<ref>{{cite web|title=Local Law Enforcement Hate Crimes Prevention Act of 2009|url=http://frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/getpage.cgi?dbname=2009_record&page=E1035&position=all|date=April 30, 2009|accessdate=June 21, 2009}}</ref> After the vote, Rep. [[Trent Franks]] (R-[[Arizona|AZ]]) claimed that [[equal protection]] regardless of status is a fundamental premise of the nation and thus the bill is unnecessary, and that, rather, it would prevent religious organizations from expressing their beliefs openly (although the bill only refers to violent actions, not speech.)<ref>{{cite web|title=The Passage of the Local Law Enforcement Hate Crimes Prevention Act|url=http://frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/getpage.cgi?dbname=2009_record&page=H4972&position=all|accessdate=June 21, 2009|date=April 29, 2009}}</ref>
The bill passed the House on April 29, 2009, by a vote of 249–175, with support from 231 Democrats and 18 Republicans, including [[Republican Main Street Partnership]] members [[Judy Biggert]] (IL), [[Mary Bono Mack]] (CA), [[Joseph Cao]] ([[Louisiana|LA]]), [[Mike Castle]] (DE), [[Charlie Dent]] ([[Pennsylvania|PA]]), [[Lincoln Diaz-Balart]] ([[Florida|FL]]), [[Mario Diaz-Balart]] (FL), [[Rodney Frelinghuysen]] ([[New Jersey|NJ]]), [[Jim Gerlach]] (PA), [[Mark Kirk]] (IL), [[Leonard Lance]] (NJ), [[Frank LoBiondo]] (NJ), [[Todd Russell Platts]] (PA), [[Dave Reichert]] ([[Washington (U.S. state)|WA]]), and [[Greg Walden]] ([[Oregon|OR]]) along with [[Bill Cassidy]] (LA), [[Mike Coffman]] ([[Colorado|CO]]), and [[Ileana Ros-Lehtinen]] (FL).<ref name="USHRollCall">{{USHRollCall|2009|223}}</ref>
On April 30, 2009, Rep. [[Todd Tiahrt]] (R-[[Kansas|KS]]) compared the bill to the novel ''[[Animal Farm]]'' and claimed it would harm free speech.<ref>{{cite web|title=All People Are Equal|url=http://frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/getpage.cgi?dbname=2009_record&page=H5046&position=all|date=April 30, 2009|accessdate=June 21, 2009}}</ref> Rep. [[George Miller (California politician)|George Miller]] (D-CA) and Rep. [[Dutch Ruppersberger]] (D-[[Maryland|MD]]) both announced that they were unable to be present for the vote, but had they been present they would each have voted in favor.<ref>{{cite web|title=Personal Explanation|url=http://frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/getpage.cgi?dbname=2009_record&page=E1024&position=all|accessdate=June 21, 2009|date=April 30, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Personal Explanation|url=http://frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/getpage.cgi?dbname=2009_record&page=E1044&position=all|accessdate=June 21, 2009|date=April 30, 2009}}</ref> Conversely, Rep. [[Michael C. Burgess|Michael Burgess]] (R-[[Texas|TX]]) claimed federal law was already sufficient to prevent hate crimes and said that had he been present he would have voted against the bill.<ref>{{cite web|title=Personal Explanation|url=http://frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/getpage.cgi?dbname=2009_record&page=E1037&position=all|accessdate=June 21, 2009|date=April 30, 2009}}</ref>
On October 8, 2009, the House passed the ''Matthew Shepard and James Byrd Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act'' as part of the conference report on Defense Authorization for fiscal year 2010.<ref>{{cite web |title=Final Vote Results for Role Call 223 |url=http://www.speaker.gov/newsroom/legislation?id=0341 |date=October 10, 2009 |publisher=Speaker of the United States House of Representatives |accessdate=October 10, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091013012757/http://www.speaker.gov/newsroom/legislation?id=0341 |archivedate=October 13, 2009 |df= }}</ref> The vote was 281–146, with support from 237 Democrats and 44 Republicans.<ref name="USHRollCall"/>
==== Senate ==== [[File:Matthew Shepard Senate.svg|thumb|400px|right|The Senate adopted amendment 1511 63-28 with 5 Republicans {{legend|#000080|Both yes}} {{legend|#0066FF|One yes, one didn't vote}} {{legend|#D42AFF|One yes, one no}} {{legend|#D40000|One no, one didn't vote}} {{legend|#800000|Both no}} {{legend|#cccccc|Both did not vote}}]] The bill again proceeded to the Senate, where it was again introduced by Kennedy on April 28, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.feminist.org/news/newsbyte/uswirestory.asp?id=11668 |title=Matthew Shepard Hate Crimes Prevention Act Introduced in Senate |publisher=Feminist.org |date=April 29, 2009 |accessdate=December 30, 2012}}</ref> The Senate version of the bill had 45 cosponsors as of July 8, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d111:SN00909:@@@P |title=Bill Summary & Status – 111th Congress (2009–2010) – S.909 – Cosponsors |publisher=thomas.loc.gov |accessdate=September 29, 2013}}</ref>
On June 25, 2009, the [[Senate Judiciary Committee]] held a hearing on the bill. [[United States Attorney General|Attorney General]] [[Eric Holder]] testified in support of the bill, the first time a sitting Attorney General has ever testified in favor of the bill.<ref>{{cite web|title=Senate Hate Crimes Hearing at 10am « HRC Back Story:|url=http://www.hrcbackstory.org/2009/06/senate-hate-crimes-hearing-at-10am/|accessdate=June 28, 2009|date=June 25, 2009}}</ref> During his testimony, Holder mentioned his previous testimony on a nearly identical bill to the senate in July 1998 (the Hate Crimes Prevention Act of 1998, S. 1529), just months before Matthew Shepard was murdered.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.advocate.com/article.aspx?id=83564|title=AG to Senate: Pass Hate Crime Bill|first=Michelle|last=Garcian|date=January 1, 2008|accessdate=June 28, 2008|work=[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]}}</ref> According to [[CNN]], Holder testified that, "more than 77,000 hate crime incidents were reported by the [[FBI]] between 1998 and 2007, or 'nearly one hate crime for every hour of every day over the span of a decade.'" Holder emphasized that one of his "highest personal priorities ... is to do everything I can to ensure this critical legislation finally becomes law".<ref>{{cite web|title=Holder pushes hate crimes law; GOP unpersuaded|url=http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2009/06/25/holder-pushes-hate-crimes-law-gop-unpersuaded/#more-57796|accessdate=June 28, 2009|date=June 25, 2009}}</ref>
Reverend Mark Achtemeier of the [[University of Dubuque]] Theological Seminary, [[Janet Langhart]], whose play was premiering at the [[United States Holocaust Museum]] at the time of the [[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum shooting|shooting]] earlier in the month and Michael Lieberman of the [[Anti-Defamation League]] also testified in favor of the bill. [[Gail Heriot]] of the [[United States Commission on Civil Rights]] and Brian Walsh of the [[Heritage Foundation]] testified in opposition to the bill.
The Matthew Shepard Act was adopted as an amendment to {{USBill|111|S.|1390}} (the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2010) by a 63–28 cloture vote on July 15, 2009.<ref name="A07-17">{{cite news|url=http://www.advocate.com/News/Daily_News/2009/07/16/Hate_Crimes_Passes,_Faces_Veto/|title=Hate Crimes Passes, Faces Veto|last=Eleveld|first=Kerry|date=July 17, 2009|publisher=[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]|accessdate=July 17, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100805002103/http://www.advocate.com/News/Daily_News/2009/07/16/Hate_Crimes_Passes,_Faces_Veto/|archive-date=2010-08-05|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> At the request of Senator [[Jeff Sessions]] (an opponent of the Matthew Shepard Act), an amendment was added to the Senate version of the hate crimes legislation that would have allowed prosecutors to seek the [[death penalty]] for hate crime murders,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://thehill.com/leading-the-news/hate-crimes-amendments-pass-easily-2009-07-20.html|title=Hate Crimes Amendments Pass Easily |last=Rushing|first=J. Taylor|date=July 20, 2009|publisher=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|accessdate=July 21, 2009}}</ref> though the amendment was later removed in conference with the House.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://lawdork.net/2009/10/08/hate-crimes-act-makes-conference-report-death-penalty-gone/|title=Hate Crimes Act Makes Conference Report, Death Penalty Gone|publisher=lawdork.net|date=October 8, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091015210146/http://lawdork.net/2009/10/08/hate-crimes-act-makes-conference-report-death-penalty-gone/|archivedate=October 15, 2009|df=}}</ref>
The bill won the support of five Republicans: [[Susan Collins]] ([[Maine|ME]]), [[Dick Lugar]] ([[Indiana|IN]]), [[Lisa Murkowski]] ([[Alaska|AK]]), [[Olympia Snowe]] ([[Maine|ME]]), and [[George Voinovich]] ([[Ohio|OH]]).
=== Passage === {{see also|National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2010}}
[[File:HR 2647 - 2009-2010 Defense Appropriations House of Representatives vote.svg|thumb|400px|right|House vote on '''2009–2010 Defense Appropriations''' {{legend|#000080|Democratic yes}} {{legend|#FF5050|Republican yes}} {{legend|#C8C8C8|Abstention or no representative seated}} {{legend|#5050FF|Democratic no}} {{legend|#800000|Republican no}}]]
[[File:HR 2647 - 2009-2010 Defense Appropriations Senate vote.svg|thumb|400px|right|Senate vote on '''2009–2010 Defense Appropriations''' {{legend|#000080|Both yes}} {{legend|#0066FF|One yes, one didn't vote}} {{legend|#D42AFF|One yes, one no}} {{legend|#D40000|One no, one didn't vote}} {{legend|#800000|Both no}}]]
The bill passed the Senate when the Defense bill passed on July 23, 2009.<ref name="senate.gov">{{cite web|url=https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=111&session=1&vote=00242 |title=Senate.gov |publisher=Senate.gov |date= |accessdate=December 30, 2012}}</ref> As originally passed, the House version of the defense bill did not include the hate crimes legislation, requiring the difference to be worked out in a [[Conference report|Conference committee]]. On October 7, 2009, the Conference committee published the final version of the bill, which included the hate crimes amendment;<ref>{{cite web|title=HRC Backstory: Conference Report Published – Hate Crimes Bill Included|url=http://www.hrcbackstory.org/2009/10/conference-report-published-hate-crimes-bill-included/}}</ref> the conference report was then passed by the House on October 8, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|title=AFP: US lawmakers pass 680-billion-dollar defense budget bill|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hkAXS0HTzkXeKMKJ8BFxiuculsPA}}</ref> On October 22, 2009, following a 64–35 cloture vote,<ref>{{cite web|title=HRC Backstory: Senate Achieves Cloture on DoD Conference Report Including Hate Crimes Provision|url=http://www.hrcbackstory.org/2009/10/senate-achieves-cloture-on-dod-conference-report-including-hate-crimes-provision/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=111&session=1&vote=00326 |title=Roll call vote |publisher=Senate.gov |date= |accessdate=December 30, 2012}}</ref> the conference report was passed by the Senate by a vote of 68–29.<ref name="hill">Roxana Tiron, "Senate OKs defense bill, 68–29", ''[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]'', found at [http://thehill.com/homenews/senate/64377-senate-to-vote-on-defense-bill# The Hill website]. Accessed October 22, 2009.</ref> The bill was signed into law on the afternoon of October 28, 2009, by President Barack Obama.<ref name="obama"/>

==Enforcement== In May 2011, a man in [[Arkansas]] pleaded guilty under the Act to running a car containing five Hispanic men off the road. As a result, he became the first person ever convicted under the Act. A second man involved in the same incident was later convicted under the Act; his appeal of that conviction was denied on August 6, 2012.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.katv.com/story/14663862/man-accused-of-violating-the-hate-crime-prevention-act|title=Man Accused of Violating the Hate Crime Prevention Act|last=Fry|first=Lindsey|date=May 23, 2011|work=[[KATV]]|accessdate=June 29, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.katv.com/story/19205778/appeals-court-upholds-hate-crime-law-in-ark-case|title=Appeals court upholds hate crime law in Ark. case|date=August 6, 2012|work=[[KATV]]|accessdate=August 6, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ca8.uscourts.gov/opndir/12/08/113254P.pdf|title=''U.S. v. Maybee'' (opinion)|publisher=[[United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit]]|date=August 6, 2012}}</ref>
In August 2011, one man in [[New Mexico]] pleaded guilty to branding a [[swastika]] into the arm of a developmentally disabled man of [[Navajo people|Navajo]] descent. A second man entered a guilty plea to conspiracy to commit a federal hate crime. The two men were accused of branding the victim, shaving a swastika into his head, and writing the words "white power" and the acronym "KKK" on his body. A third man in June 2011, entered a guilty plea to conspiracy to commit a federal hate crime. All three men were charged under the Act in December 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/08/18/2-men-plead-guilty-in-swa_n_930827.html|title=2 Men Plead Guilty In Swastika Branding Case|publisher=The Huffington Post|date=August 18, 2011}}</ref>
On March 15, 2012, the [[Kentucky State Police]] assisted the FBI in arresting David Jenkins, Anthony Jenkins, Mable Jenkins, and Alexis Jenkins of [[Partridge, Kentucky|Partridge]], Kentucky, for the beating of Kevin Pennington during a late-night attack in April 2011 at Kingdom Come State Park,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kentucky.com/2012/04/12/2148377/two-eastern-kentucky-men-indicted.html#storylink=cpy|title=2 Kentucky men face first-of-their-kind federal hate-crime charges|publisher=Lexington Herald-Leader|date=March 15, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/2012/April/12-crt-465.html|title=Two Harlan County, Kentucky, Men Indicted for Federal Hate Crime Against Individual Because of Sexual Orientation; The Indictment Marks the First Case Charged Under the Matthew Shepard and James Byrd Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act Involving Sexual Orientation|publisher=United States Department of Justice|date=April 12, 2012}}</ref> near Cumberland. The push came from the gay-rights group [[Kentucky Equality Federation]], whose president, Jordan Palmer, began lobbying the U.S. Attorney for the Eastern District of Kentucky in August 2011<ref>{{cite web|url=http://community.kyequality.org/2011/08/kentucky-equality-federation.html|title= Kentucky Equality Federation communicates with the U.S. Department of Justice about Harlan County Hate Crime|publisher=Kentucky Equality Federation Official Press Releases – Copy of request to prosecute included|date=August 24, 2011}}</ref> to prosecute after stating he had no confidence in the Harlan County Commonwealth's Attorney to act.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.kyequality.org/2012/03/louisville-ky.html|title= Kentucky advocacy group pushes first federal hate crime arrests|agency=Associated Press|date=March 15, 2013}}</ref> "I think the case's notoriety may have derived in large part from the Kentucky Equality Federation efforts," said Harvey, the U.S. Attorney for the Eastern District of Kentucky.<ref name="The Huffington Post">{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/04/17/david-jason-jenkins-anthony-ray-jenkins_n_1433047.html|title= David Jason Jenkins, Anthony Ray Jenkins Face Life In Anti-Gay Attack Under New U.S. Hate Crime Law |publisher=The Huffington Post|date=April 18, 2012}}</ref> Mable Jenkins and Alexis Jenkins pleaded guilty.<ref name="The Huffington Post"/>
In 2016, for the first time the Justice Department used the Act to bring criminal charges against a person for selecting a victim because of their gender identity.<ref name="autogenerated9">{{cite web|last=Grinberg |first=Emanuella |url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/12/22/politics/mississippi-transgender-hate-crime/ |title=Hate-crime case result historic for feds - CNNPolitics.com |publisher=Cnn.com |date= |accessdate=2016-12-22}}</ref><ref name="buzzfeed1">{{cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/dominicholden/hate-crime-law-for-transgender |title=Federal Hate Crime Law Used For Transgender Violence For The First Time - BuzzFeed News |publisher=Buzzfeed.com |date=2016-12-15 |accessdate=2016-12-22}}</ref> In that case Joshua Brandon Vallum pled guilty to murdering Mercedes Williamson in 2015 because she was transgender, in violation of the Act.<ref name="autogenerated9"/><ref name="buzzfeed1"/> In 2017, he was "sentenced to 49 years in prison and fined $20,000 for killing his ex-girlfriend because she was transgender.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/05/15/us/transgender-hate-crime-murder-sentence-mississippi/index.html|title=Hate crime: Man sentenced for killing transgender woman|last=CNN|first=Ralph Ellis, Emanuella Grinberg and Janet DiGiacomo|website=CNN|access-date=2017-05-18}}</ref>" The Justice Department reported that "[t]his is the first case prosecuted under the Hate Crimes Prevention Act involving a victim targeted because of gender identity."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdms/pr/mississippi-man-sentenced-49-years-prison-bias-motivated-murder-transgender-woman|title=Mississippi Man Sentenced to 49 Years in Prison for Bias-Motivated Murder of Transgender Woman in Lucedale, Mississippi|website=www.justice.gov|language=en|access-date=2017-05-18}}</ref>
==Court challenges== The constitutionality of the law was challenged in a 2010 lawsuit filed by the [[Thomas More Law Center]]; the lawsuit was dismissed.<ref>{{cite web|author=Ryan J. Reilly September 8, 2010, 8:45 AM |url=http://tpmmuckraker.talkingpointsmemo.com/2010/09/judge_upholds_matthew_shepard_hate_crimes_law.php |title=Judge Dismisses Challenge To Hate Crimes Law: Plaintiffs Argued Their Hate Would Cause Headaches |publisher=tpmmuckraker.talkingpointsmemo.com |date=September 8, 2010 |accessdate=December 30, 2012}}</ref>
William Hatch, who pleaded guilty to a hate crime in the New Mexico case, also contested the law on Constitutional grounds. The [[United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit|Tenth Circuit Court of Appeals]] heard the case (''U.S. v. Hatch'') and upheld the conviction on June 3, 2013.<ref name=Boetel>{{cite news|date=July 5, 2013|accessdate=January 26, 2015|first=Ryan |last=Boetel|work=[[Albuquerque Journal]]|url=http://www.abqjournal.com/217751/news/us-court-upholds-mans-hate-crime-conviction.html |title= U.S. court upholds man's hate crime conviction}}</ref>

{{About|the French philosopher}} {{pp-vandalism|small=yes}} {{Infobox philosopher |region = [[Western philosophy]] |era = [[18th-century philosophy]] |image = Montesquieu 1.png |caption = Anonymous portrait (1728) |name = Montesquieu |birth_date = 18 January 1689 |birth_place = [[Château de la Brède]], [[La Brède]], [[Aquitaine]], France |death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|1755|2|10|1689|1|18}} |death_place = [[Paris]], France |school_tradition = [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]]
[[Classical liberalism]] |main_interests = [[Political philosophy]] |influences = [[Aristotle]], [[Cicero]], [[Thomas Hobbes]], [[Polybius]], [[René Descartes]], [[Nicolas Malebranche]], [[Jean Bodin]], [[John Locke]], [[Acts of Union 1707|18th-century English constitution]] |influenced = [[David Hume]], [[Thomas Paine]], [[Jean-Jacques Rousseau|Rousseau]], [[Edmund Burke]], [[United States Constitution]] and political system, [[Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel|G.W.F Hegel]], [[Alexis de Tocqueville]], [[Émile Durkheim]], [[Hannah Arendt]], [[Adam Ferguson]], [[Jean de Sismondi]], [[Prosper de Barante]]{{cite journal |last1=Ousselin |first1=Edward |title=French Political Thought from Montesquieu to Tocqueville: Liberty in a Levelled Society? (review) |journal=French Studies: A Quarterly Review |date=2009 |volume=63 |issue=2 |page=219 |url=https://muse.jhu.edu/article/262695}} |notable_ideas = Separation of state powers: [[Executive (government)|executive]], [[legislative]], [[judicial]]; classification of systems of government based on their principles }} '''Charles-Louis de Secondat, Baron de La Brède et de Montesquieu''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|m|ɒ|n|t|ə|s|k|j|uː}};[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/montesquieu "Montesquieu"]. ''[[Random House Webster's Unabridged Dictionary]]''. {{IPA-fr|mɔ̃tɛskjø|lang}}; 18 January 1689 – 10 February 1755), generally referred to as simply '''Montesquieu''', was a French [[judge]], [[intellectual|man of letters]], and [[political philosophy|political philosopher]]. He is famous for his articulation of the theory of [[separation of powers]], which is implemented in many [[constitution]]s throughout the world. He is also known for doing more than any other author to secure the place of the word "[[despotism]]" in the political lexicon.{{Harvnb|Boesche|1990|p=1}}. His anonymously published ''[[The Spirit of the Laws]]'' in 1748, which was received well in both Great Britain and the American colonies, influenced the [[Founding Fathers of the United States|Founding Fathers]] in drafting the [[United States Constitution]]. ==Biography== [[File:Chateau la brede.jpg|thumb|left|Château de la Brède]] Montesquieu was born at the [[Château de la Brède]] in southwest France, {{convert|25|km}} south of [[Bordeaux]].{{cite web|url=https://maps.google.com/maps?client=safari&oe=UTF-8&q=bordeaux%20map&ie=UTF-8&hq=&hnear=0xd5527e8f751ca81:0x796386037b397a89,Bordeaux,%20France&gl=us&ei=J4tmUrypF8u4kQe1-oDIBA&ved=0CC4Q8gEwAA|title=Google Maps|publisher=}} His father, Jacques de Secondat, was a soldier with a long noble ancestry. His mother, Marie Françoise de Pesnel, who died when Charles was seven, was an heiress who brought the title of Barony of La Brède to the Secondat family.Sorel, A. ''Montesquieu''. London, George Routledge & Sons, 1887 (Ulan Press reprint, 2011), p. 10. {{ASIN|B00A5TMPHC}} After the death of his mother he was sent to the [[Catholic]] [[College of Juilly]], a prominent school for the children of French nobility, where he remained from 1700 to 1711.Sorel (1887), p. 11. His father died in 1713 and he became a ward of his uncle, the Baron de Montesquieu.Sore (1887), p. 12. He became a counselor of the Bordeaux [[Parliament]] in 1714. The next year, he married the [[Protestant]] Jeanne de Lartigue, who eventually bore him three children.Sorel (1887), pp. 11–12. The Baron died in 1716, leaving him his fortune as well as his title, and the office of [[président à mortier]] in the Bordeaux Parliament.Sorel (1887), pp. 12–13. Montesquieu's early life occurred at a time of significant governmental change. England had declared itself a [[constitutional monarchy]] in the wake of its [[Glorious Revolution]] (1688–89), and had joined with Scotland in the [[Union of 1707]] to form the [[Kingdom of Great Britain]]. In France, the long-reigning [[Louis XIV]] died in 1715 and was succeeded by the five-year-old [[Louis XV]]. These national transformations had a great impact on Montesquieu; he would refer to them repeatedly in his work. [[File:Montesquieu, De l'Esprit des loix (1st ed, 1748, vol 1, title page).jpg|thumb|upright|The title page of the first volume of Montesquieu's ''[[:File:Montesquieu, De l'Esprit des loix (1st ed, 1748, vol 1).pdf|De l'Esprit des loix]]'' (1st ed., 1748)]] Montesquieu withdrew from the [[lawyer|practice of law]] to devote himself to study and writing. He achieved literary success with the publication of his 1721 ''[[Persian Letters]]'', a satire representing society as seen through the eyes of two imaginary [[Persian people|Persian]] visitors to [[Paris]] and Europe, cleverly criticizing the absurdities of contemporary French society. He next published ''[[Considerations on the Causes of the Greatness of the Romans and their Decline]]'' (1734), considered by some scholars, among his three best known books, as a transition from ''The Persian Letters'' to his master work. ''[[The Spirit of the Laws]]'' was originally published anonymously in 1748. The book quickly rose to influence [[political thought]] profoundly in Europe and America. In France, the book met with an unfriendly reception from both supporters and opponents of the regime. The Catholic Church banned ''The Spirit'' – along with many of Montesquieu's other works – in 1751 and included it on the [[Index Librorum Prohibitorum|Index of Prohibited Books]]. It received the highest praise from the rest of Europe, especially Britain. Montesquieu was also highly regarded in the British colonies in [[British North America|North America]] as a champion of liberty (though not of American independence). According to one [[political scientist]], he was the most frequently quoted authority on government and politics in colonial pre-revolutionary British America, cited more by the American founders than any source except for the [[Bible]].{{Harvnb|Lutz|1984}}. Following the [[American Revolution]], Montesquieu's work remained a powerful influence on many of the American founders, most notably [[James Madison]] of [[Virginia]], the "Father of the [[U.S. Constitution|Constitution]]". Montesquieu's philosophy that "government should be set up so that no man need be afraid of another"Montesquieu, [http://etext.lib.virginia.edu/etcbin/toccer-new2?id=MonLaws.xml&images=images/modeng&data=/texts/english/modeng/parsed&tag=public&part=137&division=div2 ''The Spirit of the Laws'', Book 11, Chapter 6, "Of the Constitution of England."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928071427/http://etext.lib.virginia.edu/etcbin/toccer-new2?id=MonLaws.xml&images=images%2Fmodeng&data=%2Ftexts%2Fenglish%2Fmodeng%2Fparsed&tag=public&part=137&division=div2 |date=28 September 2013 }} Electronic Text Center, University of Virginia Library, Retrieved 1 August 2012 reminded Madison and others that a free and stable foundation for their new national government required a clearly defined and balanced separation of powers. [[File:Lettres familieres a divers amis d'Italie.tif|thumb|''Lettres familières à divers amis d'Italie'', 1767]] Besides composing additional works on society and politics, Montesquieu traveled for a number of years through Europe including Austria and [[Hungary]], spending a year in Italy and 18 months in England, where he became a freemason, admitted to the ''Horn Tavern'' Lodge in Westminster,{{Harvnb|Berman|2012|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=oQTvxkhqomsC&pg=PA150 150]}}. before resettling in France. He was troubled by poor eyesight, and was completely [[blindness|blind]] by the time he died from a high fever in 1755. He was buried in the [[Église Saint-Sulpice, Paris]]. ==Philosophy of history== Montesquieu's philosophy of history minimized the role of individual persons and events. He expounded the view in ''Considérations sur les causes de la grandeur des Romains et de leur décadence'' that each historical event was driven by a principal movement: {{Quote|It is not chance that rules the world. Ask the Romans, who had a continuous sequence of successes when they were guided by a certain plan, and an uninterrupted sequence of reverses when they followed another. There are general causes, moral and physical, which act in every monarchy, elevating it, maintaining it, or hurling it to the ground. All accidents are controlled by these causes. And if the chance of one battle{{mdash}}that is, a particular cause{{mdash}}has brought a state to ruin, some general cause made it necessary for that state to perish from a single battle. In a word, the main trend draws with it all particular accidents.{{citation |title=Considerations on the Causes of the Greatness of the Romans and their Decline|author=Montesquieu|year=1734|publisher=The Free Press|url=http://www.constitution.org/cm/ccgrd_l.htm|accessdate=30 November 2011}} Ch. XVIII.'' }} In discussing the transition from the Republic to the Empire, he suggested that if Caesar and Pompey had not worked to usurp the government of the Republic, other men would have risen in their place. The cause was not the ambition of Caesar or Pompey, but the ambition of man. == Political views == {{Republicanism sidebar}} Montesquieu is credited as being among the progenitors, which include [[Herodotus]] and [[Tacitus]], of [[anthropology]], as being among the first to extend comparative methods of classification to the political forms in human societies. Indeed, the French political anthropologist [[Georges Balandier]] considered Montesquieu to be "the initiator of a scientific enterprise that for a time performed the role of cultural and social anthropology".{{Harvnb|Balandier|1970|p=3}}. According to social anthropologist [[D. F. Pocock]], Montesquieu's ''[[The Spirit of the Laws]]'' was "the first consistent attempt to survey the varieties of human society, to classify and compare them and, within society, to study the inter-functioning of institutions."{{Harvnb|Pocock|1961|p=[https://archive.org/stream/socialanthropolo00poco#page/8/mode/2up 9]}}.
{{Harvnb|Tomaselli|2006|p=9}}, similarly describes it as "among the most intellectually challenging and inspired contributions to political theory in the eighteenth century. [... It] set the tone and form of modern social and political thought." Montesquieu's political anthropology gave rise to his theories on government. When [[Catherine the Great]] wrote her ''[[Nakaz]]'' (Instruction) for the Legislative Assembly she had created to clarify the existing Russian law code, she avowed borrowing heavily from Montesquieu's ''Spirit of the Laws'', although she discarded or altered portions that did not support Russia's absolutist bureaucratic monarchy.{{Harvnb|Ransel|1975|p=179}}. Montesquieu's most influential work divided French society into three classes (or ''[[trias politica]]'', a term he coined): the [[monarchy]], the [[aristocracy]], and the [[commons]]. Montesquieu saw two types of governmental power existing: the [[wikt:sovereign|sovereign]] and the [[Public administration|administrative]]. The administrative powers were the [[executive (government)|executive]], the [[legislative]], and the [[judicial]]. These should be separate from and dependent upon each other so that the influence of any one power would not be able to exceed that of the other two, either singly or in combination. This was a radical idea because it completely eliminated the three [[Estates of the realm|Estates]] structure of the French Monarchy: the [[clergy]], the aristocracy, and the people at large represented by the [[Estates General (France)|Estates-General]], thereby erasing the last vestige of a [[feudalism|feudalistic]] structure. His famous articulation of the theory of the [[separation of powers]] is found in ''[[The Spirit of the Laws]]'': {{Quote| «''IN every government there are three sorts of power: the legislative; the executive in respect to things dependent on the law of nations; and the executive in regard to matters that depend on the civil law.''» «''By virtue of the first, the prince or magistrate enacts temporary or perpetual laws, and amends or abrogates those that have been already enacted. By the second, he makes peace or war, sends or receives embassies, establishes the public security, and provides against invasions. By the third, he punishes criminals, or determines the disputes that arise between individuals. The latter we shall call the judiciary power, and the other, simply, the executive power of the state.''» |''[[The Spirit of the Laws]]'', Book XI{{Cite web|url=http://oll.libertyfund.org/titles/montesquieu-complete-works-vol-1-the-spirit-of-laws#lf0171-01_label_786|title=Montesquieu, Complete Works, vol. 1 (The Spirit of Laws)|website=oll.libertyfund.org|access-date=2018-03-11}}{{Cite web|url=https://fr.wikisource.org/wiki/Esprit_des_lois_(1777)/L11/C6|title=Esprit des lois (1777)/L11/C6 - Wikisource|website=fr.wikisource.org|language=fr|access-date=2018-03-11}} }} Montesquieu argues that each Power should only exercise its own functions, it was quite explicit here: {{Quote| «When the legislative and executive powers are united in the same person, or in the same body of magistrates, there can be no liberty; because apprehensions may arise, lest the same monarch or senate should enact tyrannical laws, to execute them in a tyrannical manner.» «''Again, there is no liberty if the judiciary power be not separated from the legislative and executive. Were it joined with the legislative, the life and liberty of the subject would be exposed to arbitrary controul; for the judge would be then the legislator. Were it joined to the executive power, the judge might behave with violence and oppression.''» «''There would be an end of every thing, were the same man, or the same body, whether of the nobles or of the people, to exercise those three powers, that of enacting laws, that of executing the public resolutions, and of trying the causes of individuals.''» |''[[The Spirit of the Laws]]'', Book XI}} If the legislative branch appoints the executive and judicial powers, as Montesquieu indicated, there will be no separation or division of its powers, since the power to appoint carries with it the power to revoke. {{Quote| «''The executive power ought to be in the hands of a monarch, because this branch of government, having need of dispatch, is better administered by one than by many: on the other hand, whatever depends on the legislative power, is oftentimes better regulated by many than by a single person.''» «''But, if there were no monarch, and the executive power should be committed to a certain number of persons, selected from the legislative body, there would be an end of liberty, by reason the two powers would be united; as the same persons would sometimes possess, and would be always able to possess, a share in both.''» |''[[The Spirit of the Laws]]'', Book XI}} Likewise, there were three main forms of government, each supported by a social "principle": [[monarchy|monarchies]] (free governments headed by a hereditary figure, e.g. king, queen, emperor), which rely on the principle of honor; [[republic]]s (free governments headed by popularly elected leaders), which rely on the principle of virtue; and despotisms (enslaved governments headed by [[dictator]]s), which rely on fear. The free governments are dependent on fragile constitutional arrangements. Montesquieu devotes four chapters of ''The Spirit of the Laws'' to a discussion of England, a contemporary free government, where liberty was sustained by a balance of powers. Montesquieu worried that in France the intermediate powers (i.e., the nobility) which moderated the power of the prince were being eroded. These ideas of the control of power were often used in the thinking of Maximilien de [[Robespierre]]. Montesquieu advocated reform of slavery in ''The Spirit of the Laws''. As part of his advocacy he presented a satirical [https://en.wikiquote.org/wiki/The_Spirit_of_the_Laws#Book_XV:_In_What_Manner_the_Laws_of_Civil_Slavery_Relate_to_the_Nature_of_Climate hypothetical list of arguments for slavery]. While addressing French readers of his ''General Theory'', [[John Maynard Keynes]] described Montesquieu as "the real French equivalent of [[Adam Smith]], the greatest of your economists, head and shoulders above the physiocrats in penetration, clear-headedness and good sense (which are the qualities an economist should have)."See the [https://www.scribd.com/doc/11392072/The-General-Theory-of-Employment-Interest-and-Money preface] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141110212009/https://www.scribd.com/doc/11392072/The-General-Theory-of-Employment-Interest-and-Money |date=10 November 2014 }} to the French edition of Keynes' ''General Theory''.
See also {{Harvnb|Devletoglou|1963}}. == Meteorological climate theory == Another example of Montesquieu's anthropological thinking, outlined in ''[[The Spirit of the Laws]]'' and hinted at in ''[[Persian Letters]]'', is his [[meteorological]] climate theory, which holds that [[climate]] may substantially influence the nature of man and his society. By placing an emphasis on environmental influences as a material condition of life, Montesquieu prefigured modern anthropology's concern with the impact of material conditions, such as available energy sources, organized production systems, and technologies, on the growth of complex socio-cultural systems. He goes so far as to assert that certain climates are superior to others, the temperate climate of France being ideal. His view is that people living in very warm countries are "too hot-tempered", while those in northern countries are "icy" or "stiff". The climate of middle Europe is therefore optimal. On this point, Montesquieu may well have been influenced by a similar pronouncement in [[Histories (Herodotus)|''The Histories'' of Herodotus]], where he makes a distinction between the "ideal" temperate climate of Greece as opposed to the overly cold climate of Scythia and the overly warm climate of Egypt. This was a common belief at the time, and can also be found within the medical writings of Herodotus' times, including the "On Airs, Waters, Places" of the Hippocratic corpus. One can find a similar statement in ''[[Germania (book)|Germania]]'' by [[Tacitus]], one of Montesquieu's favorite authors. [[Philip M. Parker]] in his book ''Physioeconomics'' endorses Montesquieu's theory and argues that much of the economic variation between countries is explained by the physiological effect of different climates. From a sociological perspective [[Louis Althusser]], in his analysis of Montesquieu's revolution in method,{{Harvnb|Althusser|1972}}. alluded to the seminal character of anthropology's inclusion of material factors, such as climate, in the explanation of social dynamics and political forms. Examples of certain climatic and geographical factors giving rise to increasingly complex social systems include those that were conducive to the rise of agriculture and the domestication of wild plants and animals. == List of principal works == {{French literature sidebar}} * Memoirs and discourses at the Academy of Bordeaux (1718–1721): including discourses on echoes, on the renal glands, on weight of bodies, on transparency of bodies and on natural history. * ''Spicilège'' (''Gleanings'', 1715 onward) * ''Système des idées'' (''System of Ideas'', 1716) * ''[[Persian Letters|Lettres persanes]]'' (''Persian Letters'', 1721) * ''Le Temple de Gnide'' (''The Temple of Gnidos'', a prose poem; 1725) * ''[[:fr:Histoire Véritable|Histoire véritable]]'' (''True History'', a reverie; c. 1723–c. 1738) * ''[[Considerations on the Causes of the Greatness of the Romans and their Decline|Considérations sur les causes de la grandeur des Romains et de leur décadence]]'' (''Considerations on the Causes of the Greatness of the Romans and their Decline'', 1734) at [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b8613371v/f7.image.r=.langEN Gallica] * ''Arsace et Isménie'' (''Arsace and Isménie'', a novel; 1742) * ''De l'esprit des lois'' (''[[The Spirit of the Laws|(On) The Spirit of the Laws]]'', 1748) ([[:File:Montesquieu, De l'Esprit des loix (1st ed, 1748, vol 1).pdf|volume 1]] and [[:File:Montesquieu, De l'Esprit des loix (1st ed, 1748, vol 2).pdf|volume 2]] from [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ Gallica]) * ''La défense de «L'Esprit des lois»'' (''In Defence of "The Spirit of the Laws"'', 1750) * ''Essai sur le goût'' (''Essay on Taste'', pub. 1757) * ''Mes Pensées'' (''My Thoughts'', 1720–1755) A definitive edition of Montesquieu's works is being published by the Société Montesquieu.
